hero.hook: Hi, I'm Jason Mason! This is my web webumé for the Front End Engineer position at Chess.com. Send me a message or give me a call and we'll talk!

coverLetter.body:
Hey Chess.com! Instead of writing the typical cover letter where I go over how qualified I am and talk about how I resonate with the Chess.com values and blah blah blah, I just wanted to get real.
I love chess. I play it almost every day, and my wife gets mad at me because we have an 8-month-old who demands things. Funny enough, it was her idea to have me apply here. She said, "How about you apply at Chess.com?" and I said, "Amazing idea." That was in 2021 when I saw you guys were using Svelte, and I said, "Awe! I want to learn Svelte so badly, but they probably won't hire me because I don't have a proven track record." Que web development montage where I spend the next few years freelancing and getting my chops up, working with referrals from past employers. And now, I can say that I'm pretty proficient at Svelte, and I don’t like freelancing, so I told my wife, "Alright, it's time to apply at Chess.com."
So, it was my big moment, and then I realized that you guys are using Vue now, and I said, "Crap!" But at this point, and after learning tools like Svelte in about a week, I've realized that it doesn't matter what technology somebody throws at me; I can learn it fast. So I’m applying anyway.
Now, here's the pertinent question: why should Chess.com give me a shot? I'm certainly not the most seasoned applicant, and I can guarantee that. Nor am I the 170 IQ ex-Google architect GOAT. I'm just a guy who's been the technical-can-do man for marketing teams and business development (as you'll see in my portfolio below). So why should you give me a shot? Well, for one, I use vim. But more importantly, I would be incredibly grateful and feel extremely blessed to be able to work at Chess.com, perfecting a craft that I love (web development).
Gratitude sounds cliché, but I've noticed in my professional career that the people who are the greatest value generators for companies are those who see what they do as more than a career but a craft and are truly grateful that they have a chance to do it every day. And I know 100% I'm bringing that to the table.
Listen, I know you'd be taking a risk on me here, and that's why I'm willing to come work with Chess.com for free for a month. If you don't like me, or you think I'm not capable of delivering substantial value to the company, no worries; we can part ways without hard feelings, and I will be grateful for the opportunity. I hope that mitigates the risk for you and displays my passion for both web development and chess (which, as a side note, I'm super excited to be able to have a legitimate excuse to reach my Elo goals while playing more chess).
Now, with that type of offer on the table, how can we not set up at least an initial interview?! Thanks for the consideration.
Cheers

profile.body:
Mustache-less front-end developer and designer with a mustache logo for his personal brand. Thinks he can work at Chess.com despite being a 1000 Elo noob. Builds user interfaces for fun and spent way too much time architecting the perfect Neovim config. Learned differential calculus in two days to build a neural network for a dinosaur video game, then forgot it.

Avid drummer specializing in gospel chops. Spent a thousand hours on the road just to see 4 tornadoes. Spends more time than he would like to admit gawking at pro snowboarders doing quad corks in slow motion. Puts Jesus on his resume knowing recruiters make fun of him, but still keeps it 100.

records.description: Built websites that obtained and secured top search rankings on Google for over 3 years in the #1 most competitive chiropractic market in the world. Built automated customer journeys and attribution reporting by synchronizing marketing automation, CRM, analytics, and EHR technology implementations. Results yielded a 30% increase in cash profits leading to acquisition.

Leveraged brand style guides to design and build pixel perfect, fully responsive landing pages and company websites using HTML, CSS,  JQuery, and WordPress. Drove internal improvements to MarTech stack amid political and financial resistance. Researched and developed personas that fueled messaging. Built and deployed automated campaigns that generated leads in the roofer segment for the first time in the company's history. Wore the hat of SalesForce admin/developer and built systems using Apex that drove internal adoption of the SalesForce platform. Implemented customer journeys and marketing automation.

Designed and built pixel perfect, fully responsive JAMstack websites leveraging Figma, headless content management, REST and GraphQL APIs, SCSS, CSS in JS, and component-driven javascript web frameworks like Next JS and Sveltkit. Implemented automated customer journeys and campaigns in marketing automation web applications. Built custom components that seamlessly integrate websites with MarTech stack using Google, Zoho, and SalesForce APIs. Built custom SalesForce functionality using Apex and the SalesForce Developer Platform. Consulted marketing leaders on MarTech stacks. Built and maintained marketing attribution dashboards that tracked customers through every stage of the funnel up to initial sale.
